abstract: Shanghai Forte Land, a Chinese property developer, is in talks to buy a high-end residential property in Shanghai from Goldman Sachs, in a deal worth more than $200 million, Reuters reported.
snippet: Shanghai Forte Land, a Chinese property developer, is in talks to buy a high-end residential property in Shanghai from Goldman Sachs, in a deal worth more than $200 million, Reuters reported.
lead_paragraph: Shanghai Forte Land, a Chinese property developer, is in talks to buy a high-end residential property in Shanghai from Goldman Sachs, in a deal worth more than $200 million, Reuters reported, citing two people familiar with the situation.

headline.main: Forte in Talks to Buy Goldman’s Shanghai Property

abstract: Eleven Chinese brokerages including Citic Securities and Haitong Securities will vie to be included in a pilot program for margin trading and short selling following a nationwide test run in 2008, The China Securities Journal reported.
snippet: Eleven Chinese brokerages including Citic Securities and Haitong Securities will vie to be included in a pilot program for margin trading and short selling following a nationwide test run in 2008, The China Securities Journal reported.
lead_paragraph: Eleven Chinese brokerages including Citic Securities and Haitong Securities will vie to be included in a pilot program for margin trading and short selling following a nationwide test run in 2008, The China Securities Journal reported, citing an unidentified regulator.

headline.main: Chinese Brokers Vie for Trading Program

abstract: ESolar, a U.S. solar power company whose investors include Google and Oak Investment Partners, said it will help build a series of solar thermal power plants in China, as the country tries to decrease its reliance on coal, imported gas and oil.
snippet: ESolar, a U.S. solar power company whose investors include Google and Oak Investment Partners, said it will help build a series of solar thermal power plants in China, as the country tries to decrease its reliance on coal, imported gas and oil.
lead_paragraph: ESolar, an American solar power company whose investors include Google and Oak Investment Partners, said Saturday it would help build a series of solar thermal power plants in China, as the world’s biggest emitter of greenhouse gases tries to decrease its reliance on coal, imported gas and oil.

headline.main: ESolar Strikes Deal to Build China Plants
